column4: Hey. How can I assign an alias to a host? I want to say ssh hostname instead of ssh 192.168.1.14
you can manually map names to ips in /etc/hosts
then you need 2 names. like host and host-ext
All right, that's not too much of a hassle. Thanks!
by random people? they need to have an account, no?   you can encrypt your data

It's an audio workstation for my church. The random people who use the account that automatically logs in. I could go the route of a separate account, I guess, but I'd still need it secured. How does one encrypt data?
there are several ways. you can encrypt single files (nautlis encrypt, gnupg) or partitions or loop mounted disk images (loop-aes)
but multiple people that access the data is not so easy.

Which encryption way is the best? I'd just put it all in a folder, say "Videos" or "Music" and lock down the folder. rmitchell I'd still be able to stream, though, right? What if I used, say, a mediatomb?
if you are the only one with root access, using file permissions can also help, so that others can not look at your files. but someone that can boot a live cd can access them
I'm not. The default account (the one that automatically logs in) also has adminstrative privileges.
with ecryptfs (creates a Private folder) partitions and loop-aes you need to have the files mounted to access them. the file permissions (should) ensure that no one else on the box sees these files
Could I use ecryptfs and have a mediatomb or jinzora user access the files?
it's going to be difficult if an oter user has admin rights too..

Okay, plan change. What is the best way to hide a folder on the default account, and still allow "system users" to access it? It doesn't have to be ultra-secure, most of the people around here aren't too tech-savvy.
you can create a folder somewhere and use the file permissions. you can create a separate group for all non admin users that are allowed to use it. but each users needs his own account
All right. I think I'm getting ideas now.
default accound for random users with admin rights.. you're sure you want that?
I know, right? That's what I said. But sometimes they need to install stuff (like today Sound Converted needed to be installed quickly.)
you can restrict sudo to single applications. so you could only allow synaptic, but that also not a perfect solution
How does that work?
man sudoers
Thanks.
